questions.text: A patient with iron deficiency anemia is started on oral iron supplementation. When would you expect to see the PEAK reticulocyte response, indicating that the bone marrow is actively producing new red blood cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 7-10 days after starting therapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy: This is too soon to expect a peak response. It takes several days for the bone marrow to ramp up red blood cell production.
  • • Option A.
  • • Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy:
  • • Option B. 3-4 days after starting therapy: While the reticulocyte count may start to rise within 3-4 days, the peak response is typically later.
  • • Option B. 3-4 days after starting therapy:
  • • Option D. 14-21 days after starting therapy: This is too late for the peak response. If there's no significant increase by this time, it could suggest a lack of response to therapy or an alternative diagnosis.
  • • Option D. 14-21 days after starting therapy:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The reticulocyte count is a valuable tool for monitoring the response to iron therapy in iron deficiency anemia. An increase in reticulocytes within 4-7 days and a peak response at 7-10 days are expected findings, indicating that the treatment is effective.

questions.text: Which of the following alpha-globin gene arrangements is MOST likely to be associated with Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) --/-α

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. αα/αα: α-thal. With Myelodysplasia - Mutations in ATRX ; striking male predominance. Hematologic findings of HbH disease.
  • • Option A. αα/αα:
  • • Option B. -α/αα: Represents the silent carrier state of alpha-thalassemia, with only one alpha-globin gene deleted. It typically doesn't cause significant clinical symptoms.
  • • Option B.
  • • -α/αα:
  • • Option C. --/αα: Represents alpha-thalassemia trait, where two alpha-globin genes are deleted. This condition can lead to mild anemia but is not associated with HbH disease.
  • • Option C.
  • • --/αα:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The specific arrangement and number of alpha-globin gene deletions determine the severity of alpha-thalassemia. HbH disease, a moderate form of the condition, is caused by the deletion or inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes, represented by the genotype --/-α (other gene arrangement: α T α/- -, α T α/α T α)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of mild anemia on routine blood work presents for a follow-up appointment. She reports good energy levels and denies any recent illnesses or blood loss. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. Which of the following hematological conditions is MOST likely represented in this blood smear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Beta-thalassemia intermedia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: While also microcytic and hypochromic, it usually does not exhibit target cells or the degree of poikilocytosis seen here.
  • • Option A. Iron deficiency anemia:
  • • Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Causes macrocytic (large red blood cell) anemia, not microcytic.
  • • Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency:
  • • Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Characterized by sickle-shaped red blood cells, which are not present in this image.
  • • Option C. Sickle cell anemia:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The presence of target cells, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, hypochromia and microcytosis in a blood smear strongly suggests beta-thalassemia intermedia.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia and acrocyanosis that worsens in cold weather. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity

questions.correct_answer: C. Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity and Option B. Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity are more commonly associated with WAIHA.
  • • Option A. Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity
  • • Option
  • • B. Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity
  • • Option D. Negative DAT : A negative DAT would not be expected in a patient with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
  • • Option D.
  • • Negative DAT
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • A positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity is a key laboratory finding in the diagnosis of CAS.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lymphoma presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (WAIHA)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cold agglutinin disease (CAD): Primarily presents with acrocyanosis and anemia, and blood smear often reveals agglutination.
  • • Option A. Cold agglutinin disease (CAD):
  • • Option B. Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH): Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) is rare and typically presents with biphasic hemolysis and hemoglobinuria after cold exposure.
  • • Option B. Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH):
  • • Option D. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): Presents with schistocytes on peripheral smear and is associated with underlying conditions like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).
  • • Option D. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA):
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • WAIHA is the most common type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and can be associated with underlying lymphoproliferative disorders like lymphoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with sickle cell disease (SCD) and a history of frequent vaso-occlusive crises is being considered for treatment with crizanlizumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets P-selectin. What is the PRIMARY mechanism of action of crizanlizumab in preventing vaso-occlusive crises in SCD?

options.label: D
options.text: Blocking adhesive interactions between sickle cells and endothelial cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Blocking adhesive interactions between sickle cells and endothelial cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blocking adhesive interactions between sickle cells and endothelial cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increasing fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels: Hydroxyurea, not crizanlizumab, is the primary medication used to increase HbF levels in sickle cell disease.
  • • Option A. Increasing fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels:
  • • Option B. Decreasing red blood cell sickling: While reducing adhesion can indirectly help prevent sickling, crizanlizumab's primary mechanism is not directly targeting the sickling process itself.
  • • Option B. Decreasing red blood cell sickling:
  • • Option C. Inhibiting platelet aggregation: While platelets play a role in vaso-occlusion, crizanlizumab's primary target is P-selectin on endothelial cells, not platelets.
  • • Option C. Inhibiting platelet aggregation:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • P-selectin blockade is a novel therapeutic approach in SCD that targets the adhesive interactions involved in vaso-occlusion.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of worsening fatigue. His mother reports that he seems to have trouble keeping up with his older brothers when playing outside. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed. This patient's results are shown in comparison to those of a patient with known sickle cell anemia and a child with normal hemoglobin. Based on this electrophoresis, which of the following types of hemoglobin are dominant in this patient's blood?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HbS and HbC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. HbC only: Individuals homozygous for HbC have hemoglobin C disease, which typically manifests with mild anemia. The electrophoresis pattern of a patient with HbC disease would show a single thicker band that migrates even less than HbS.
  • • Option A. HbC only:
  • • Option B. HbA and HbC: Individuals with the hemoglobin C trait would have both HbA and HbC in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbC but not HbA. Moreover, hemoglobin C trait is usually an asymptomatic carrier state, unlike this patient with fatigue.
  • • Option B. HbA and HbC:
  • • Option C. HbA and HbS: Individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait would have both HbA and HbS in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbS but not HbA. Moreover, individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait are usually asymptomatic, unlike this patient with fatigue.
  • • Option C. HbA and HbS:

questions.text: A 28-year-old African American woman presents with mild anemia and complains of intermittent abdominal pain. On peripheral blood smear, target cells and rhomboid crystals are noted within red blood cells. Given the likely diagnosis, Which of the following amino acid changes is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glutamic acid to lysine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Valine to glutamic acid: This substitution is the characteristic change for sickle cell anemia (HbS).
  • • Option B. Valine to glutamic acid:
  • • Option C. Lysine to glutamic acid: Swapping these two positively charged amino acids would likely have a minimal effect on hemoglobin function.
  • • Option C. Lysine to glutamic acid:
  • • Option D. Glutamic acid to valine: This substitution is also seen in HbS and leads to the polymerization of red blood cells.
  • • Option D. Glutamic acid to valine:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • HbC disease is a milder form of hemoglobinopathy compared to sickle cell disease, but it is important to distinguish it based on the specific amino acid substitution.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with G6PD deficiency presents with jaundice and fatigue. Her laboratory results show hemoglobin of 8 g/dL and elevated indirect bilirubin. Which of the following medications would be MOST likely to trigger this hemolytic episode?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nitrofurantoin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acetaminophen : Acetaminophen is not a common trigger of G6PD deficiency-related hemolysis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Acetaminophen
  • • Option B. Penicillin : Penicillin is generally safe in G6PD deficiency.
  • • Option B.
  • • Penicillin
  • • Option C. Ciprofloxacin : Ciprofloxacin is not a common trigger of G6PD deficiency-related hemolysis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Ciprofloxacin
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • It is crucial to avoid medications that can trigger hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with hereditary spherocytosis presents with right upper quadrant pain. Ultrasound reveals gallstones. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of gallstone formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased pigment excretion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increased cholesterol secretion: While cholesterol is a major component of gallstones, increased secretion is not the primary culprit in HS.
  • • Option A. Increased cholesterol secretion:
  • • Option B. Decreased bile acid synthesis: Decreased bile acid synthesis can promote cholesterol gallstones, but it is not a major factor in pigment gallstone formation seen in HS.
  • • Option B. Decreased bile acid synthesis:
  • • Option D. Decreased gallbladder motility: Decreased gallbladder motility can contribute to gallstone formation, but it is not the most specific or common finding in HS.
  • • Option D. Decreased gallbladder motility:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Gallstones are a common complication of hereditary spherocytosis due to increased pigment excretion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and dark urine, especially in the morning. Laboratory tests reveal hemoglobinuria and decreased levels of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: While it can present with anemia and hemolysis, it typically does not cause hemoglobinuria or have decreased CD55/CD59 levels.
  • • Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
  • • Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: This usually presents with episodic hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress, not specifically at night.
  • • Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:
  • • Option D. Sickle cell disease: This is a genetic hemoglobinopathy with distinct clinical and laboratory findings.
  • • Option D. Sickle cell disease:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • PNH is a rare acquired hemolytic anemia characterized by intravascular hemolysis, often more pronounced at night, and decreased CD55 and CD59 levels on blood cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line treatment for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ravulizumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Prednisone: While corticosteroids like prednisone may be used in some cases of autoimmune hemolytic anemia, they are not the first-line treatment for PNH. They are less effective than eculizumab or ravulizumab at controlling hemolysis and thrombosis.
  • • Option A. Prednisone:
  • • Option C. Rituximab: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets B cells. While it can be used in some autoimmune disorders, it is not indicated for PNH.
  • • Option C. Rituximab:
  • • Option D. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used in various conditions, including organ transplantation and some autoimmune disorders. It has no direct effect on the complement system, which is the primary driver of PNH, and thus is not used in its treatment.
  • • Option D. Cyclosporine:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Eculizumab and ravulizumab have revolutionized the treatment of PNH by significantly reducing hemolysis, thrombosis risk, and improving quality of life.

questions.text: Flow cytometry in a patient with suspected aplastic anemia is most likely to reveal:
questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased or absent CD34+ cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased or absent CD34+ cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increased CD34+ cells: This would be seen in conditions with increased hematopoietic activity, such as recovery from chemotherapy or certain leukemias. It's not expected in aplastic anemia where the bone marrow is failing.
  • • Option A. Increased CD34+ cells:
  • • Option C. Increased blasts: Increased blasts (immature blood cells) would suggest acute leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), not aplastic anemia.
  • • Option C. Increased blasts:
  • • Option D. Monoclonal B-cell population: This finding would be more indicative of a lymphoproliferative disorder, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) or lymphoma, rather than aplastic anemia.
  • • Option D. Monoclonal B-cell population:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Flow cytometry can help confirm the diagnosis of aplastic anemia by demonstrating a lack of CD34+ cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old vegan presents with fatigue, pallor, and numbness and tingling in their hands and feet. Which of the following laboratory findings would be MOST consistent with the suspected diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Microcytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level

options.label: B
options.text: Macrocytic anemia and elevated MMA level

options.label: C
options.text: Macrocytic anemia and normal MMA level

options.label: D
options.text: Normocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine level

questions.correct_answer: B. Macrocytic anemia and elevated MMA level
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Macrocytic anemia and elevated MMA level

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Microcytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level: Microcytic anemia is associated with iron deficiency, not B12 deficiency.
  • • Option A. Microcytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level:
  • • Option C. Macrocytic anemia and normal MMA level: While macrocytic anemia is consistent with B12 deficiency, normal MMA levels would not be expected.
  • • Option C. Macrocytic anemia and normal MMA level:
  • • Option D. Normocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine level: Normocytic anemia is not typical of B12 deficiency, and while homocysteine can be elevated in both B12 and folate deficiencies, it's not specific for B12.
  • • Option D. Normocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine level:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Vitamin B12 deficiency should be suspected in vegans presenting with neurological symptoms and macrocytic anemia. Elevated MMA levels are a specific marker for B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is MOST likely to interfere with folate metabolism and potentially lead to folate deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aspirin: While aspirin can cause some minor interference with folate absorption at very high doses, it's not a major contributor to folate deficiency at typical doses.
  • • Option A. Aspirin:
  • • Option B. Metformin: Metformin primarily affects glucose metabolism and doesn't have a direct impact on folate metabolism. However, long-term metformin use has been associated with mild decreases in vitamin B12 levels, which can sometimes be confused with folate deficiency.
  • • Option B. Metformin:
  • • Option D. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a cholesterol-lowering medication (statin) and does not interfere with folate metabolism.
  • • Option D. Atorvastatin:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • While all medications should be reviewed when a patient presents with folate deficiency, methotrexate stands out as the most likely culprit due to its direct inhibitory effect on dihydrofolate reductase, a key enzyme in folate metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic modifications on chromosome 9 leads to the formation of the B antigen?

options.label: A
options.text: Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen

options.label: B
options.text: Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of fucose from the H antigen

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen

questions.correct_answer: B. Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen: This modification results in the formation of the A antigen.
  • • Option A. Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen:
  • • Option C. Removal of fucose from the H antigen: While removal of fucose is a step in the formation of both A and B antigens, it's not the final step for the B antigen.
  • • Option C. Removal of fucose from the H antigen:
  • • Option D. Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen: This results in the O blood group, where neither A nor B antigens are present.
  • • Option D. Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The A and B antigens are formed by modifications of the H antigen.

questions.text: A patient experiences a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) 5 days after a blood transfusion. Which of the following blood group systems is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kidd

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Kell: While Kell antibodies can cause severe hemolytic reactions, these are typically acute rather than delayed.
  • • Option A. Kell:
  • • Option C. MNS: MNS antibodies can cause delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions, but they are relatively rare compared to Kidd antibodies.
  • • Option C. MNS:
  • • Option D. Lewis: Lewis antibodies are naturally occurring and typically of the IgM isotype, which are generally not considered clinically significant in transfusions.
  • • Option D. Lewis:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Kidd antibodies are typically IgG and can cause severe delayed reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following antigen is resistant to P. vivax/knowlesi?
questions.correct_answer: B. DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. K/k: Kell antigens are a group of antigens found on red blood cells. They are not involved in malaria resistance.
  • • Option A. K/k:
  • • Option C. Lewis Ag: Lewis antigens are present in body fluids and can be adsorbed onto red blood cells. They do not play a role in malaria resistance.
  • • Option C. Lewis Ag:
  • • Option D. A antigen: The A antigen is part of the ABO blood group system and determines blood type. It has no relationship to malaria susceptibility.
  • • Option D. A antigen:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines (DARC) is essential for P. vivax and P. knowlesi malaria parasites to invade red blood cells. Individuals without this receptor are naturally resistant to these types of malaria.

questions.text: A patient's blood sample is mixed with Anit-A/B/D and the findings are shown below. What is the patient's blood type?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) B+

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of easy bruising and pinprick red spots on her lower legs. She denies any recent injuries or medication use. On examination, she has multiple petechiae on her skin and mucous membranes. Blood investigations except low platelet count, imagings turned out to be normal. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aplastic anemia : While it can cause thrombocytopenia, it also affects other cell lines (red blood cells and white blood cells).
  • • Option A. Aplastic anemia
  • • Option C. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) : MDS can cause thrombocytopenia, but it is more common in older adults and often presents with other cytopenias.
  • • Option C. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
  • • Option D. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) : TMA causes thrombocytopenia through a different mechanism (platelet consumption in microvascular thrombi).
  • • Option D. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA)
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of thrombocytopenia need to be ruled out.

questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic woman has a routine complete blood count (CBC) which shows a platelet count of 80,000/µL. Peripheral blood smear shows large platelet clumps. Given the likely diagnosis, Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the CBC in a sodium citrate tube

questions.correct_answer: A. Repeat the CBC in a sodium citrate tube
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeat the CBC in a sodium citrate tube

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Start corticosteroids for ITP : Corticosteroids are used to treat ITP, but this is not appropriate until pseudothrombocytopenia is ruled out.
  • • Option B. Start corticosteroids for ITP
  • • Option C. Order a bone marrow biopsy : A bone marrow biopsy is not necessary for the diagnosis of pseudothrombocytopenia.
  • • Option C. Order a bone marrow biopsy
  • • Option D. Begin heparin therapy for HIT : Heparin therapy is contraindicated in HIT and should not be started until this diagnosis is ruled out.
  • • Option D. Begin heparin therapy for HIT
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Repeating the CBC in a citrate tube is a simple and effective way to confirm pseudothrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with fatigue, easy bruising, and petechiae. His platelet count is 20,000/µL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Secondary ITP associated with CLL
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Secondary ITP associated with CLL

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Primary immune thrombocytopenia (ITP): While ITP presents with isolated thrombocytopenia, the presence of CLL suggests a secondary cause in this case.
  • • Option
  • • A. Primary immune thrombocytopenia (ITP):
  • • Option B. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia: There is no mention of recent medication use to suggest this diagnosis.
  • • Option
  • • B. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia:
  • • Option C. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT): HIT is an immune-mediated reaction to heparin, which is not mentioned in the patient's history.
  • • Option C.
  • • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT):
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Secondary ITP can be caused by various underlying conditions, including lymphoproliferative disorders like CLL.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a 5-year history of chronic ITP has persistent thrombocytopenia (25,000/µL) despite prior treatments with corticosteroids, IVIg, and TPO-RAs. She experiences frequent bleeding and seeks further management options. Which of the following is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Splenectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Rituximab infusion: While rituximab can be effective in some patients, its response rate is lower than splenectomy and the onset of action is delayed. It also carries potential for serious side effects like infections and infusion reactions.
  • • Option
  • • A. Rituximab infusion:
  • • Option C. Danazol therapy: Danazol is an older medication with limited evidence of efficacy in ITP and potential for masculinizing side effects in women, making it a less preferred option.
  • • Option
  • • C. Danazol therapy:
  • • Option D. Fostamatinib therapy: This is a newer option with promising results, but it has less long-term data than splenectomy and may have adverse effects like hypertension, diarrhea, and hepatotoxicity.
  • • Option
  • • D. Fostamatinib therapy:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • In patients with chronic ITP refractory to initial therapies, splenectomy offers the highest chance of long-term remission, but it should be considered after weighing the risks and benefits of surgery. Other options like rituximab and fostamatinib may be considered in select cases, while danazol is less commonly used due to its limited efficacy and side effect profile.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman develops new-onset thrombocytopenia and thrombosis 6 days after initiating unfractionated heparin (UFH) for DVT prophylaxis following knee replacement surgery. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type II Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) : ITP is an autoimmune disorder that can cause thrombocytopenia but is not typically associated with thrombosis.
  • • Option A. Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
  • • Option B. Type I Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT): This is a non-immune mediated form of HIT that usually occurs within the first 2 days of heparin exposure and is not associated with thrombosis.
  • • Option B. Type I Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT):
  • • Option D. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP): TTP is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and neurologic symptoms. It is not typically associated with heparin use.
  • • Option D. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP):
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • New-onset thrombocytopenia and thrombosis in a patient recently started on heparin should raise suspicion for Type II HIT, which warrants immediate discontinuation of heparin and initiation of alternative anticoagulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical clinical feature of Thrombotic Microangiopathy (TMA)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prolonged PT and PTT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Thrombocytopenia : A key feature of TMA due to platelet consumption in microthrombi.
  • • Option A.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent pyogenic skin and respiratory infections, silver-grey hair, and nystagmus. Peripheral blood smear reveals giant granules in neutrophils. questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor procedures undergoes laboratory testing. questions.text: Which blood additive provides the longest shelf life for stored red blood cells?

questions.text: A patient with severe liver disease presents with a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and is scheduled for an invasive procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate blood product for correcting their coagulopathy?
